title: The Stones of Blood
dialogue_triumphs: Romana: 'What's it say?' Doctor: 'I don't know, I can't read the script.'
goofs: How does de Vries control the ravens, and what is their function?
At the start of the story there are three Ogri. One falls off a cliff, but later there are still three.
If Cessair has escaped from the prison ship, why does she stay on Earth? What's her plan?

continuity_notes.name: White Guardian
continuity_notes.description: Powerful being who sent the Doctor and Romana on their mission, rather than the President of the Time Lords.

continuity_notes.name: Third Segment of the Key to Time
continuity_notes.description: A powerful artifact with abilities of transmutation, transformation, and establishing hyperspacial and temporal coordinates.
continuity_notes.current_status: Sought by the Doctor and Romana

continuity_notes.name: Cessair of Diplos
continuity_notes.description: Criminal from Diplos who evaded justice and has been living on Earth for 4000 years, adopting different guises.
continuity_notes.current_status: Hiding on Earth, controlling the stone circle

continuity_notes.name: Ogri
continuity_notes.description: Silicon-based life-forms from the planet Ogros, deficient in globulin.

continuity_notes.name: Megara
continuity_notes.description: Justice machines that pursued Cessair of Diplos.
continuity_notes.current_status: Seeking to bring Cessair to justice

technobabble: Type 40 TARDISes are fitted with molecular stabilisers: after an attack by an Ogri K-9's circuits are regenerated by connecting this stabiliser to his circuit frequency modulator.
Mending the hyperspace 'gun', amongst other things, involves linking the alpha circuit to the sine interphase.
roots: The Hound of the Baskervilles (missing portrait)
Brief mentions of Tacitus and John Aubrey
Oblique reference to Polonius in Hamlet
links: There seems to be a Wirrn ('The Ark in Space') and a (weird) Kraal android skeleton ('The Android Invasion') in the ship in hyperspace.

locations.name: The Nine Travellers
locations.description: A stone circle on Boscombe Moor, near Boscawen, Damnonium (Cornwall)

locations.name: Diplos
locations.description: A G-class planet in the Tau Ceti system, home of Cessair

locations.name: Ogros
locations.description: Planet covered with amino acid swamps, home of the Ogri

additional_notes: Cessair is allergic to citric acid. The Doctor mentions a Galactic Federation that appointed a justice machine, which, finding the Federation to be in contempt of court, blew up the entire galaxy.
bottom_line: The first two episodes are delightfully Hammeresque, but the last half of the story, largely centred on the ship in hyperspace and the Doctor's defence of himself against the Megara, is woeful. There's a weird robot-thing with eyelashes and red lips stuck next to Romana in her cell, and the Doctor just so happens to carry a barrister's wig with him. Ultimately the story disappoints as whole acres of motivation and background are glossed over.
